After the first Dashlet competition I started writing addons and pieces of code for Alfresco & the community. Now a days I'm developing a lot of stuff, mainly custom modules and I try to blog once in a while.

• Addons: Alfresco Advanced Folder Search, Alfresco AND Search, YouTube Dashlet, Move2Folder
    • Blogs: http://www.contezza.nl/blog, http://blog.mitco-solutions.com/

name: Morgan
summary:
A young French guy of 24 years old. Morgan got an engineering degree in computer science a little bit less than 2 years ago. He was born and still live in France but he works in Switzerland.

Morgan discovered Alfresco almost 4 years ago and that day, he decided to become a "Middleware Man". Morgan is working in the Middleware Team of "dbi services", a Swiss IT Consulting company. Within this team, guys mainly work with several application servers (WebLogic, JBoss, Tomcat, Apache, OHS, aso...), several DMS (Documentum, SharePoint, Alfresco) and some other open source technologies like Kerberos. Morgan joined this enterprise a little bit more than 2 years ago since his "end of studies internship" consisted in the analysis and comparison of several Document Management Systems for dbi services - of course, Alfresco was chosen ;). Since that day, he installed, configured and administered Alfresco (Community or Enterprise editions) for customers and company internal use.
contributions:
• Morgan likes to use his company's website to post some blogs entries related to Open Sources technologies including Alfresco.
  • Morgan also has an account on the Alfresco forum. He tries to spend at least 1h per week to read the Alfresco Forum for new posts, maybe to find something to add aso...

name: Jeff
summary: I've been involved in implementing and selling ECM solutions for the past 14+ years. During that time, I was working as a developer, tech lead, architect and for the last 6 years or so a Sales Engineer. While I've been on the sales end of things, the company I currently work for has been an Alfresco partner and I've been through training and demoed Alfresco many times over the years. I'm leaving my current company shortly to work with another Alfresco partner and moving back to an implementation role and would like to get more into development and involved in the community. I've always been an advocate of open source software and really liked the vibe of Alfresco in the early days. As I move back to solution architecture and development I'd like to give back to the community, get more depth in Alfresco, and work with like minded people.
contributions:
• A few years back Jeff did a couple wiki updates and added a page on correctly configuring CIFS and getting that working with various Windows versions.
  • Jeff is working on making more contributions to the community

I'm a main contributor of some of the most important Alfresco deployments in Chile, as independent consultant and as partner of Impulse IT, in the past and the present.

name: Bindu
summary: I am the chief architect at Zia Consulting, which is a Platinum Parter of Alfresco. We have been partner of the year a couple of times. As a platinum partner we can't work on community projects through work. However, there is nothing stopping folks working on community related projects in our spare time :)
contributions:
• I enjoy hanging out on IRC and answering questions if I can. I presented a dev environment we built during TTL #69 that I hope inspired the new RAD stuff in the 2.0 SDK at least a little bit.
  • I have also presented some lightning talks at DevCon/Summit and will be presenting a full session at Summit in SF and London this year that I hope will be interesting to (and advocating for) the community.

name: Atef
summary:
I am a 28 year-old Tunisian software engineer living in Paris, France. I have a 4 year-experience in ECM / BPM. First, I worked on an ECM solution based on Alfresco. I was heavily involved in the design and implementation of workflow designer based on JointJS and Raphaël. The workflow designer is partially compliant with BPMN 2.0 providing intuitive UI and making the deployment of new workflows including tasks model, forms configuration and Activiti process definition with just few clicks.

Actually, I am working on several projects around Alfresco Community and Alfresco Enterprise Editions. My tasks include: requirements analysis, sizing Alfresco platform, customization and features design, evolutions analysis and implementation, issues analysis and fixing, auditing, security, etc. I am an Alfresco Certified Engineer (ACE) and an Alfresco Certified Administrator (ACA).
contributions: Not yet developed an open source add-on. But, it is coming soon...

name: Ole
summary: I've been working with Alfresco for 3.5-4 years. I haven't had much luck with the community in the past, but this changed last year and I decided to go all in and participate as I realised that I could make a difference.
contributions:
• Very active in the IRC channel, helping out answering questions, and a couple of times doing PoC projects for others who are struggling.
  • Write a tutorial about the Aikau framework.
  • Mavenize the old Alfresco SDK.
  • Dedicate 6 weeks of my free time to work on Alfresco related projects.
  • Help test 5.0.a's newly mavenized build process before release
  • Deeply involved in the development of Alfresco SDK 2.0 with RAD support
  • Participated in Tech Talk Live.
  • Working on an update of the Danish language pack for 5.0.a.

name: David
summary:
I've been working on Share and the APIs it uses for 4.5 years, after joining Alfresco's engineering team. I've touched most areas of Share, its APIs, but calendar, date/time and localisation and hybrid sync issues keep finding their way to my desk. I come from a web development background, so love the fact that client side technologies just won't stand still.

Recently I've been working on moving existing Share functionality to Aikau, the 5.0 search improvements as well as background tasks like development environment improvements, bringing in Grunt, simplifying maven usage and the way we run UI unit tests.
contributions:
• I blog at http://blogs.alfresco.com/wp/dwebster/.
  • I have code at https://github.com/davidcognite.
  • I try and make code to the Summits, where I usually present a session or two on new Share developments and enjoy the hack-a-thons.
